citation.article-title: Legionella pneumophila serogroup Lansing 3 isolated from a patient with fatal pneumonia, and descriptions of L. pneumophila subsp. pneumophila subsp. nov., L. pneumophila subsp. fraseri subsp. nov., and L. pneumophila subsp. pascullei subsp. nov.

p.s: Description of Legionella pneumophila subsp. fraseri subsp. nov.

Legionella pneumophila subsp. fraseri (fra'ser. i; M.L. genitive nounfraseri, in honor of David W. Fraser, who headed the investigation of the Legionnaires' disease outbreak in Philadelphia that led to the recognition of legionellosis and to the isolation of L. pneumophila [11])
Legionella pneumophila subsp. fraseri presently contains strains from serogroups 1, 4, and 5, as well as Lansing 3, the only confirmed strain of serogroup Lansing 3.
Strains in serogroups 4 and Lansing 3 do not hydrolyze hippurate, whereas all strains in serogroups 1 and 5 do.
The type strain of L. pneumophila subsp. fraseri is Los Angeles 1 (ATCC 33156), which is in serogroup 4.
DNAs from all strains of the subspecies are related to Los Angeles 1 at the species level (>70% optimal relatedness, <3% divergence in related sequences, >60% stringent relatedness).
DNA relatedness to other subspecies is below the species level in at least one and usually at least two of the hybridization parameters above.
By enzyme typing, strains within the subspecies are related at a genetic distance of 0.32 and are separated from the other subspecies at a distance of approximately 0.52 (24).
The G+C content is 38 to 39 mol%.
It has been isolated from human sputum and blood and from water and is a causative agent of Legionnaires' disease.
The type strain Los Angeles 1, isolated from human lung tissue (18), has G+C content of 39 mol%.
